However, the structure of the hydrate formed by the enclathration of neon in ice II has not been determined. Here, we report the structure of neon hydrate at high pressure and temperature. The structure is determined by neutron diffraction and is found to be in excellent agreement with the simulation results. This work provides a new route to study the structure of ice II and the properties of hydrates at high pressure and temperature. It also provides a new route to study the structure of ice II and the properties of hydrates at high pressure and temperature.

The foundations of quantum mechanics are a major open problem in the history of science. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum mechanics. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the mathematical foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. The approach is based on the notion of a Hilbert category, which is a generalization of a category that generalizes the notion of a Hilbert space. The axioms are formulated in terms of the category of Hilbert categories and the notion of a morphism of Hilbert categories. The axioms are shown to be equivalent to the axioms of quantum mechanics. The approach provides a framework for the study of the foundations of quantum mechanics that is independent of any particular mathematical formalism.

The Myxozoa are a diverse group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present the first genome assemblies for two species of myxozoans, which are related to the stinging cells of cnidarians. Our results show that myxozoans are a sister group to the cnidarian parasite Polypodium hydriforme and that the myxozoan body plan was reduced to a microscopic parasitic lifestyle accompanied by extreme genome reduction. These results provide insights into the origin of the Myxozoa and the evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic one. (Show more)

In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are critical for induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We found that SARS-CoV-2 uses a viral accessory protein, Orf6, to block nuclear import of the cargo-receptor complex. We show that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain. We also show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its ability to block nuclear import of the cargo-receptor complex. These findings provide a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. The proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Climate change is expected to increase the variability of global crop yields, which will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses. This will have important implications for global food security, especially for the 800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. We show that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results highlight the importance of breeding for heat tolerance, which is a key adaptation strategy for the future. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of large mammals in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of species matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that diversity of large mammals may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This may have important implications for the management of African savanna.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, which are the backbone of the U.S. economy. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses anticipate problems accessing the CARES Act loans, which are currently the only available source of financing.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of small plastic fragments by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the elements is one of the most important questions in astrophysics. The formation of presolar grains in the ejecta of asymptotic giant branch stars is one of the most promising scenarios. However, the origin of the oldest presolar grains is still a matter of debate. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of <300 Ma and condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago. This is the oldest age yet determined for presolar grains.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to provide resources to offspring correlates with increased reproductive output. We find that domestication and all forms of allocare correlate with increased fertility. All forms of provisioning correlate with larger litters without compromising offspring size. The greatest increase we observe in reproductive power is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This study has important implications for understanding the evolution of reproduction and the evolution of domestication. It also has implications for understanding the evolution of allonursing in humans.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. Our results suggest that VX-765, a drug that was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the development of a treatment for MSA.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most numerous cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cells that are connected by a network of communication channels. The network is designed to be both local and global in nature, allowing for the rapid and efficient control of the body’s vascular system. This paper describes the design of the endothelial network and the properties that make it effective for the control of cardiovascular activity. The findings have implications for understanding the function of the endothelium and for developing new strategies for controlling cardiovascular disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, especially for public health surveillance and epidemiological modeling. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 surveillance signals, including many that are not available elsewhere. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are extracted from a variety of sources, including deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are a large family of ion channels that are involved in a wide variety of physiological and pathological processes. They are involved in the regulation of heart rate, blood pressure, and breathing, among other functions. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the selectivity of the channel for K+ ions. The selectivity filter is closed in the inactive state and is opened upon channel activation. We have identified a key residue that is involved in the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. This allosteric communication is crucial for the proper functioning of the channel.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical to the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is just beginning to be understood, and the potential for the microbiome to be manipulated for therapeutic purposes is being explored. The gut microbiome is also a dynamic system, and the composition of the microbiome can change rapidly in response to environmental changes. This study shows that anaerobic fungi, which are a component of the gut microbiome, synthesize natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome. This study also shows that anaerobic fungi are capable of producing a wide variety of natural products, including antibiotics, which could be used to treat infections caused by gut bacteria. These results provide insight into the potential of anaerobic fungi to be used as a source of natural products for therapeutic purposes.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in determining social rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate during a social encounter, directly influences social dominance in rats and that this effect is mediated by mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We provide evidence that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and that it is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of anxiety in social behavior and may lead to the development of new therapeutic approaches for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to design and manufacture mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors is of great importance for various applications. However, the design of such devices is often limited by the complexity of the target behaviors and the material properties of the constituent materials. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design and manufacture multifunctional mechanical devices with programmable behaviors. The proposed strategy is based on the inverse design of composite structures composed of multiple materials with distinct properties. The synthesized structures are then manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, which allows the structures to be assembled into architectures with highly complex behaviors. The proposed strategy can be extended to design multifunctional mechanical devices with programmable behaviors for various applications.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development and differentiation in vertebrates. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in human erythroid tissues and that its expression is developmentally regulated. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 can reprogram the hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythroid cells, resulting in a more fetal-like pattern. This is achieved by reduced expression of the adult hemoglobin alpha and beta genes and increased expression of the fetal hemoglobin alpha gene. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids, in cancer cells. This resistance is mediated by activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which, in turn, activates sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. We show that SREBP1-mediated lipogenesis is required for this resistance, and that this resistance can be overcome by inhibiting mTORC1 and inducing ferroptosis. These findings have important implications for the development of new cancer therapies. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cardiovascular disease and the leading cause of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the mechanisms of action of LCCBs are not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate the STIM/ORAI Ca2+ signaling pathway in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs), which is associated with the development of vascular remodeling. Our data indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our findings may help to understand the mechanisms of action of LCCBs and may lead to the development of new drugs for treating hypertension.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP has not yet been successful in reversing the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This work is expected to contribute to the development of new antibiotics. View Full-Text

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes it difficult to train the networks with a large number of training samples. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. Our results show that the proposed architecture is a promising alternative to existing architectures for many image-processing problems. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for the community of researchers working on image-processing problems.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become increasingly common, but the biological effects of this exposure on sleep and health are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) for 1 h before bedtime phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and reduces the next-morning alertness. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event in the Holocene climate record. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the event. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope ratios of magnetic grains and microspherules from the YDB sites are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In contrast, the Osmium isotope ratios of bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os, but the Os in these samples is likely terrestrially derived. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of spherules from the YDB indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been extensively studied, but the impact of CTLA-4 in the adult mouse has not been investigated. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in the adult mouse. We found that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity in a variety of organs, including the lung, gut, and pancreas. In addition, we found that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity in the thymus, which is not required for the development of autoimmunity in the periphery. These findings indicate that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in both the thymus and the periphery.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Our results show that the origin of beetles coincides with the origin of the plant kingdom, and that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained via horizontal gene transfer may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of beetles. This study also shows that diversification of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivores following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding plant cell wall-degrading enzymes. This study thus provides a new perspective on the origin and diversification of beetles. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report the results of a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of human culture and the origins of technology.

The strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE isoform is associated with a twofold decreased risk for AD. APOE is also a major protein of astrocytes, a major cell type in the central nervous system that is highly phagocytic. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis of synapses by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also found that APOE alleles are associated with different levels of C1q accumulation in the central nervous system. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,340 km, which is the size of a small country. It is the densest part of the Earth, with a density of 12.0–12.9 g/cm3, and is the only part of the Earth that is not molten. The inner core is a mystery because it is difficult to understand how it formed. We show that the inner core formed by a two-step process. First, the molten iron cooled to a temperature below the melting point, but above the solidification point, and then the molten iron nucleated into a solid sphere. This mechanism explains the inner core nucleation paradox, which is a long-standing problem in geophysics. This mechanism also provides a clue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the inner core. This work provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core.

The brain’s dopamine system is critical for motivation, learning, and reward. In the context of the opioid crisis, the need to understand the brain’s dopamine system is urgent. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain dopamine responses to methylphenidate, a drug that increases dopamine in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased addiction and craving.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s mechanisms for comprehending it are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the most accurate artificial neural network models of language processing in the brain are also the simplest, consisting of just a few layers of computation. These models explain nearly all of the predictive information in the data, and they generalize across datasets and imaging modalities. We discuss how these results may inform our understanding of language comprehension in the human brain. They also suggest that the most powerful artificial neural network models may be the best tools we have for understanding the brain’s mechanisms for language.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific and engineering applications. However, it is not clear whether the success of DL is due to the inherent properties of deep networks or to the special properties of the problems that were solved. We show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs) that can solve the problem with great accuracy. However, there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This implies that the success of DL is not due to the properties of deep networks, but rather to the special properties of the problems that were solved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act quickly enough, the failure of the pharmaceutical industry to develop a vaccine quickly enough, and the failure of people to comply with public health measures. One of the most prominent arguments is that people are unable to understand exponential growth. This argument is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. Here, we discuss the critical design flaws of this experiment and show that they undermine the conclusion of the study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which causes the nerve-damaging disease leprosy, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes a non-neuropathic form of leprosy known as lepromatous leprosy. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that M. lepromatosis has retained the ability to cause disease in the nervous system, and that the two bacteria have diverged little since they separated from their common ancestor. Thus, despite their ancient separation, the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions.

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the two pillars of quantum statistical mechanics. However, the relation between them is still not fully understood. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics in integrable systems can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit, which is the most difficult regime to handle. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find excellent agreement with numerical simulations. Our work provides a powerful tool to understand the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. The only vaccine currently available for use in humans is the one developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, which requires two doses, each administered 21 days apart. This study describes a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that can be administered as a single dose. The vaccine is highly attenuated, and the virus replicates poorly in the lungs of hamsters. In addition, the vaccine protects hamsters from lethal challenge with wild-type SARS-CoV-2. This study demonstrates that a single dose of the vaccine can provide protection against COVID-19. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. (Simplified version available)

The Second Pandemic of plague, which occurred between the 14th and 19th centuries, led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown, but it is thought to have been spread by rats. Here, we show that a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1347–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of using Bayesian inference to fit models to historical data.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic in comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain neuronal density is not. This study fills this gap by using the largest dataset of its kind to reconstruct the evolution of brain neuronal density across amniotes. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The role of TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) in cancer has been controversial. Some studies have shown that TRAP1 is a tumor promoter, whereas others have shown that TRAP1 is a tumor suppressor. Here we show that TRAP1 is a metabolic regulator that promotes the switch from oxidative phosphorylation to aerobic glycolysis and fatty acid oxidation, and that it promotes invasiveness. These data suggest that TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements that are responsible for many cellular processes, including cell migration. Actin filaments are also the main targets of the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family of proteins. ADF/cofilin are key regulators of actin filament dynamics, but how they do so is still not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin can sever actin filaments in a mechanical context, which is relevant to cells. We find that ADF/cofilin can induce a torque on the filaments, which enhances severing. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for how ADF/cofilin can sever actin filaments in cells. They also provide a new perspective on how actin filaments are severed in other contexts, such as in the formation of stress fibers. Our results have important implications for our understanding of cell migration and for the development of new strategies for cancer therapy.

Fructose, a sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is a popular choice for dieters because it is calorie-free. However, the effects of fructose on appetite and food intake are not well understood. Here, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may promote feeding behavior and may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. Future research should examine the effects of fructose on weight gain and the long-term consequences of its use. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique, with a recent arrival of Malagasy people, and a sex-biased and geographically heterogeneous settlement. These results show that a few centuries are enough to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This is important for the understanding of the human history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. It also has implications for the study of human migrations and the origin of the Malagasy language. We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This constitutes experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. In contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social networks, and for the way that people use social networks to manage their emotions.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary source of information for protein synthesis in cells. The presence of mRNA modifications has been shown to impact mRNA stability, translation, and protein function. Here, we show that the presence of one of the most common modifications, pseudouridine (Ψ), can alter the rate of protein synthesis. We also show that Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in coding regions can alter the rate of protein synthesis and that the ribosome can encounter Ψ in both coding and noncoding regions. These findings have implications for the function of mRNA modifications and the translation of mRNA in cells. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, stronger social relationships, and a healthier lifestyle. These associations are robust to a range of potential confounders and predictors, and they are maintained over time. The feeling that life is worthwhile may be a key factor in promoting healthy aging and sustaining social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of body size is a central topic in biology. The aquatic mammals are a unique group of animals that have colonized the water and diversified, and we show that the aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of body size in these animals. The common cold is the most common infectious disease in the world, and rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication has been attributed to a cooler core body temperature, but the molecular basis of this phenomenon has not been elucidated. Here we show that mouse-adapted rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We also show that the temperature-dependent phenotype is dependent on the RIG-I–like receptor signaling pathway, which is activated by the synthetic RLR ligand poly I:C. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis of rhinovirus temperature dependence and may lead to the development of strategies to combat rhinovirus infection. Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and they have evolved a variety of mechanisms to sense and respond to environmental signals. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense surfaces. This mechanosensory system is required for attachment to surfaces, and it regulates the production of virulence factors and biofilm formation. The type IV pili-mediated surface sensing system is a unique example of a mechanochemical signaling pathway that measures the mechanical activity of the cell surface. This finding has important implications for understanding the role of pili in bacterial motility and virulence. It also provides insights into the evolution of bacterial sensing systems. (Show more)

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and this has led to increasing contamination of surface waters. This study provides a comprehensive metaanalysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface waters and the risk they pose to aquatic biodiversity. We show that the use of pesticides in agriculture is a major threat to the biological integrity of global water resources. The results suggest that the use of pesticides in agriculture should be reduced worldwide, and that the existing environmental regulations should be strengthened.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the virus has spread to many animal species. Although deer are susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection, the virus has not been documented circulating in free-living deer. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in the lymph nodes of free-living and captive deer in Iowa. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 lineages from deer and humans are geographically clustered, suggesting multiple human-to-deer transmission events. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a robust “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This study highlights the need for a proactive approach to monitor the spread of SARS-CoV-2 in animals. (Show more)

The hydropower industry has been building dams in the developing world since the 1970s. This paper studies the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins in the brain. Although the role of Aβ in the initiation and progression of AD is well established, the role of microglial activation in the AD pathogenesis is less clear. Here, we show that neurons, which are the primary producers of Aβ, are also the source of microglial activation. We demonstrate that neurons are burdened with increasing levels of Aβ, which are known to be the most toxic amyloid species within the brain. We also show that neurons are vulnerable to Aβ-induced damage, and that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain may precede the formation of Aβ-based pathologies. Thus, we propose that neurons are a major source of the inflammatory response in AD, and that this neuron-derived inflammatory response may be a critical component in the AD pathogenesis.

The domestication of chickens (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most important events in human history. The earliest evidence for the domestication of chickens is based on the analysis of archaeological remains. However, the earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is still missing. Here we present the results of a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread at that site. We further show that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism of stress signaling in bacteria. However, the cellular response to this stress signal has remained elusive. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to remove the nucleoside monophosphates capping bacterial RNAs, also removes the dinucleoside tetraphosphate caps. Unexpectedly, this enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and morbidity. Although there are several therapeutic strategies to treat sepsis, there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore immune function and decrease immunosuppression in sepsis. We demonstrated that citrulline administration was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides evidence for the use of citrulline as a nutritional supplement in the general population. This is an important step toward the development of a new nutritional strategy to prevent and treat sepsis. View Full-Text

The biomass of all living organisms is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass pyramid of the global marine food web contains more consumers than producers. Our analysis highlights the importance of the global biomass of humans and the need for a more complete understanding of the biomass of wild mammals. This information is essential for the development of a sustainable future.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time and, in the long run, the rate of change of the system is constant. This paper is about a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the classical sandpile model. We show that the model is a continuous version of a pattern-formation model, which is a continuous version of the classical sandpile model. We also show that the model is related to proportional growth phenomena.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum devices, and energy storage. However, its electronic properties are difficult to control, and its bandgap is difficult to tune. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be tuned reversibly by strain engineering. This work offers opportunities for diamond to be used in a variety of applications. It also provides a new method to control the properties of other materials with a wide bandgap. This work is expected to be useful for the development of new materials and devices.

The role of plant immune peptides in the defense of plants against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the structural basis for the antifungal activity of plant immune peptides is not known. Here, we report the structure of a unique antifungal peptide from the nodules of a model legume, and demonstrate that it is a potent fungicide against multiple plant fungal pathogens. We also show that this peptide binds to bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro and that it binds to the fungal cell wall and penetrates the cell membrane at discrete foci, followed by gradual loss of turgor, subsequent accumulation in the cytoplasm, and elevated levels in nucleoli of germlings. This work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of plant immune peptides and opens up the possibility of using them as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This is an important advance in the field of plant immunity.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and sperm must be able to adapt to the female reproductive tract in order to complete their functional maturation. Although the male–female interface is well studied, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. We used proteomics and isotopic labeling to study the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that sperm undergo substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, through its A1 domain. Platelet function is altered in von Willebrand disease (VWD), a common disorder of the blood. We show that force application to platelets switches the A1 domain to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD and the effects of mutations in the A1 domain. The results also suggest that the A1 domain is a mechanosensitive protein. This is the first demonstration of a mechanism for the effects of force on a protein in the bulk phase. The results have implications for the effects of force on other proteins. (Read less)

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that live in and on humans, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which can be used to study the human virome and its impact on human health. The database includes information on the location of the virus in the human body, the size of the virus, and the disease associated with the virus. This database will be useful for researchers studying the human microbiome and its impact on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the Earth’s climate system. However, the ACI is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe the diurnal aerosol loading and cloud microphysical properties simultaneously. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of great interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is important for understanding the origin and evolution of life. The temperature of the Earth’s surface has been inferred from isotopic data, but this has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding the isotopic record. We here present a method for determining the temperature of the Earth’s surface based on the thermostability of ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that the temperature of the Earth’s surface decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are important for the normal function of the nervous system and cardiovascular system. They are also involved in the pathophysiology of many diseases. Ion channels are composed of protein subunits, and the pore gates of ion channels are the sites where ion flow occurs. We studied the relationship between the activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery of the K+ channel BK. We found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its rates and extents inversely correlate with channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of ion channels. It also provides a theoretical basis for the development of drugs that can regulate ion channels. It is also important for the understanding of the pathophysiology of many diseases.

The malaria parasite must overcome a number of physical barriers to successfully invade the red blood cell (RBC) and initiate infection. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses a number of strategies to overcome these barriers, including the binding of parasite adhesins to specific receptors on the RBC surface. However, we also show that the parasite can alter the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process, suggesting that the malaria parasite is not simply a mechanical system, but rather a complex system that is able to interact with the host cell to facilitate entry. However, its electronic properties are difficult to control, and its bandgap is difficult to tune. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be tuned reversibly by strain engineering. This work offers opportunities for diamond to be used in a variety of applications. It also provides a new method to control the properties of other materials with a wide bandgap. This work is expected to be useful for the development of new materials and devices.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following influenza challenge. We find that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in mice deficient in caspase-1/11, an enzyme involved in host defense against influenza infection. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the mechanisms of dry air-induced influenza disease severity. They also suggest that dry air may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza disease severity. Our study may also have implications for understanding the impact of climate change on human health. (Simplified version available)

The brain’s processing of language is a complex and highly integrated process. Although it is widely assumed that the brain builds a tree-like structure of syntactic relations, the neurophysiological evidence for this assumption has been limited. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This pattern of activity is consistent with a bottom-up parser that merges words into phrases, and it provides initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists. Our results suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that is involved in development, cell fate, and cell migration. The pathway is regulated by two key components, Axin and Dishevelled (Dsh), which are both involved in the regulation of the pathway. We show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which allows for tissue-specific regulation of the pathway. This is an important finding that may be useful in understanding the regulation of other redundant gene pairs in vertebrates.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. It is known that LH neurons can stimulate eating, but the mechanisms involved have not been fully characterized. Here we show that stimulation of LH neurons causes animals to eat vigorously, and that this effect is blocked by dopamine antagonists. We also show that dopamine is not required for the LH effect in the periphery, but is required for the LH effect in the LH itself. This suggests that dopamine is involved in the transition from the LH effect to the actual act of eating. Thus, dopamine may be involved in the transition from the LH effect to the actual act of eating.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to fix nitrogen in the soil is a valuable trait for agriculture. However, the use of nitrogen-fixing bacteria in agriculture is limited by the lack of a sustainable way to control the release of nitrogen from the symbiosis. Here, we demonstrate the ability to control the release of nitrogen from a nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in plants. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work is a step toward the development of a sustainable nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in agriculture. (Show more)

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and it is under threat from deforestation. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are a promising tool for forest monitoring, but they are rarely used to deter deforestation. We study a community monitoring program that facilitated transfer of alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the difficulty of measuring the effects of the program. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals are surrounded by sound, but most of them are not able to hear it. This is because their hearing organs are constrained by the size of their bodies. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear the sound of its prey, even though it is much smaller than the prey itself. We show that the spider’s web is an acoustic antenna that is able to detect the sound of its prey, and that the spider can localize the direction of the sound. This is a unique example of how animals can sense the world around them, even though they are not able to hear it.

The health and climate impacts of anthropogenic emissions are difficult to disentangle. We show that removing fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The role of ALK in the development of neural crest-derived tissues is well established. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk signaling is required for the development of iridophores, a type of neural crest-derived pigment cells. We further show that ALKALs, secreted small ALKAL proteins, are ligands for zebrafish ALK/LTK and that ALKALs activate ALK/LTK signaling in vitro and in vivo. Our results provide evidence that ALK/Ltk signaling is involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues and suggest a role of ALKALs in the regulation of ALK/Ltk signaling. This is of importance for the understanding of ALK/Ltk signaling in cancer.

The emergence of plague, a disease that has plagued humanity for millennia, is a complex and poorly understood process. We present the genomes of 17 ancient Yersinia pestis strains, dating from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia. This dataset allowed us to explore the diversity of the pathogen during this critical period of development. Our results suggest that the pathogen was not a single lineage but rather a single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. (Show more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management of agricultural lands is often at odds with SOC storage, as intensive crop production on grassland-derived soils liberates massive amounts of carbon to the atmosphere. This study shows that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage and mineral-associated organic carbon on these soils, but the mechanisms by which these practices increase SOC storage are not well understood. We show that the addition of legumes and manure to annual cropping systems, as well as the use of diverse, rotationally grazed pastures, can increase soil microbial biomass and C-use efficiency, but do not significantly increase mineral-associated organic carbon or total SOC storage. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to increase SOC storage on agricultural lands. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify host, viral, and environmental risk factors contributing to spillover and spread of viruses in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. Using data from virus discovery projects and public records of virus detections around the world, we ranked the spillover potential of 887 wildlife viruses. The top 12 were known zoonotic viruses, including SARS-CoV-2. The SpillOver platform can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts animals to flowers. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also show that the red color of the nectar is attractive to pollinators of this species. We identify nesocodin in the red nectar of two distantly related species, Jaltomata herrerae and Nesocodon, and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work demonstrates that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation.

The genetic history of Europe is a complex story of migrations and invasions, but the genetic history of the majority of the population during the period of the Roman Empire and the Early Middle Ages is largely unknown. Here we present the genome of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between the 5th and 7th centuries AD. The analysis of the genomes indicates that women had a much more complex history of migrations than men, and that some individuals had genetic ancestry from southeastern Europe. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This study provides a unique resource for the study of the genetic history of Europe during the Early Middle Ages.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is responsible for ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the origin and evolution of MERS-CoV and may help in the development of strategies to combat future bat coronavirus threats to human health. This

The ability to rapidly identify pathogens in resource-scarce settings is critical to mitigating epidemics. We used a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. We found that chikungunya virus presaged a larger national outbreak of more than 6,000 cases. Pathogen-agnostic mNGS investigation of febrile persons in resource-scarce settings is feasible and revealing of a diverse pathogen landscape. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be used to investigate undifferentiated febrile illness in other resource-scarce settings.

The human genome is replicated in a complex process involving multiple proteins and enzymes. One of the most important enzymes in this process is DNA polymerase δ (pol δ), which is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that pol δ maintains a loose association with the PCNA sliding clamp while replicating DNA and that this association is lost on stalling at a DNA lesion. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique insight into the molecular basis of lagging strand synthesis in humans. It also provides a unique model system for studying the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. This system can be used to study the role of the PCNA sliding clamp in DNA replication and repair.
