The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In the laboratory, the evolution of life has been achieved by the stepwise addition of proteins to an RNA-based system. Here, we show that the addition of a single RNA molecule can lead to the evolution of a functional RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA molecules, amplify them, and synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules. This represents a major step toward the reconstruction of life in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to show that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and proximity to other attractive neighborhoods. These results are consistent with three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and social health of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex, and the immune characteristics of patients with severe COVID-19 are still unclear. We have identified that the pathogenic T cells and inflammatory monocytes with large amount of interleukin 6 secreting may incite the inflammatory storm, which may potentially be curbed through monoclonal antibody that targets the IL-6 pathways. Tocilizumab, which improved the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients, is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

The role of metal micronutrients in the growth and development of fungi is well established, but the existence of metal-binding natural products in fungi is less so. Here we report the discovery of a fungal natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. The existence of this natural product in filamentous fungi suggests a previously unknown role for eukaryotic natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and the mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This discovery has implications for the role of metal homeostasis in fungal pathogenesis and the development of antifungal agents. (Show more)

The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2, in a sedimentary mudstone at Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary environment is unusual, and its formation at high temperatures is even more so. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals, and the sedimentary mudstone is derived from a source region in the crater wall/rim/central peak region. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary environment is consistent with the hypothesis that the Martian surface was once warm and wet.

Frost is a major environmental stressor of plants and animals in the Northern Hemisphere, but the geographic distribution of frost events and the evolutionary impact of these events on plants are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that this change is already affecting the performance of trees. Our findings can inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the mechanisms by which they contribute to disease are not well understood. Here we show that Th17 cells can contribute to the development of classic Th1 cells and that this process requires the expression of both the transcription factors T-bet and STAT4. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease and that targeting both Th17 and Th1 cells may be an effective strategy for the treatment of this disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, which are the cells responsible for sending signals to the muscles to move. We have previously shown that astrocytes, the cells that surround and support motor neurons, can cause motor neuron degeneration in ALS. Here, we show that motor neuron toxicity is also caused by astrocytes derived from living ALS patients. This is the first report of a rapid, highly reproducible method to produce astrocytes from living ALS patients. This will enable rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify therapies that can alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This will also provide a source of cells for cell-based therapies. This work will help us to understand the disease mechanism and develop therapies for ALS. (Simplified version available)

The ability of pathogens to influence the composition of the host microbiota is a key factor in pathogen colonization and disease. Here, we show that the tick-borne pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which is capable of altering the composition of the gut microbiota. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of the host microbiota and may have implications for the development of strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of vertebrates. However, the origin of the modern avian body plan is obscured by the limited known diversity of early branching members of the clade Pygostylia. Here, we describe a basal member of the Pygostylia, Jinguofortis perplexus, that adds important information about the origin of the modern avian body plan. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. This study also provides important information for understanding the origin of the modern avian body plan and the evolution of flight. (Show more)

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of water vapor. This is because water vapor is the most important greenhouse gas, and it is the most important ingredient in the water cycle. We show here that the water cycle is also important in the climate system.

Vertebrates have a wide variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. This ability is called color polymorphism. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green colors in vertebrates has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that this phenomenon is related to the presence of a specific group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a compound that is formed when the pigment in the blood, called hemoglobin, breaks down. Our results provide evidence of the recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study also provides a molecular basis for the evolution of blue-green colors in vertebrates.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death. The identification of factors that promote the development of breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) is important for the development of new therapeutic strategies. Here, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, which demethylates NANOG mRNA, thereby increasing NANOG levels and the percentage of BCSCs. Thus, ALKBH5 expression in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment promotes the development of BCSCs, which are responsible for the metastatic potential of breast cancer. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. (Show more)

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. The Latin term abortivum in many sources has led some scholars to suggest that fetal skins were used, arguing that it would not be possible to sustain herds if so many pocket Bibles were produced from fetal skins. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine parchment does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding the causes and consequences of the extinction. The age model presented here is based on the age of the Permian-Triassic boundary, which is defined by the onset of a global extinction and the beginning of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle. The carbon cycle was highly volatile during the extinction and recovery, and the age model presented here will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. This will allow a more accurate evaluation of the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Show more)

The intestinal epithelium is the first line of defense against pathogens and environmental toxins. However, the intestinal epithelium is also the site of chronic inflammation, which is a major cause of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). IBD is a major health problem, and there is a need for new therapeutic strategies. Here, we show that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also show that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3)-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including IBD. This study provides insights into the role of RORα in intestinal homeostasis and inflammation. (Simplified version available)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system and for neutralizing antibodies. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the ACE2 receptor, and we have compared the structure of the spike in the presence and absence of the D614G mutation. We find that the D614G mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. This work provides a structural basis for the increased infectivity of the D614G mutant virus. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, with Black and Latino Americans experiencing a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. They are also the key to understanding the chemistry of compounds. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. We show that our results are consistent with the pressure-induced metallization of the elements. Our results are also predictive, and can be used to predict the behavior of elements under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can alter the global carbon cycle. However, the effects of climate change on fire activity are uncertain, and the role of human ignitions is poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography can reduce fire activity, which can offset some of the warming caused by increasing greenhouse gas emissions. This is especially true under lower emission scenarios, which are more likely to be realized. Our results highlight the importance of human ignitions in shaping fire regimes and the potential for climate–fire feedbacks to slow global warming.

The mutualism between symbiotic bacteria and their animal hosts is one of the most common and successful forms of symbiosis in the animal kingdom. The bacteria, in exchange for a safe environment, provide the animal with a variety of nutrients. However, the mechanisms that regulate the provision of nutrients to these bacteria are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is critical for the maintenance of a mutualism between a squid and its symbiotic bacteria. This glycan is provided by the squid, and the bacteria are able to metabolize it only at night, when the squid is producing light. This glycan is thus used to regulate the activity of the symbionts. This is the first example of a glycan being used to regulate the activity of a symbiont. (Show more)

The ability to identify latent patterns in text data is critical to many applications. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify latent patterns in the narratives of the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This approach can be extended to other domains and applications. We believe that this method will be useful to researchers in many fields.

The second plague pandemic, which started in the Mediterranean in the 14th century, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. Here, we show that this pandemic was the consequence of repeated introductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our results suggest that the Black Death was not a single event but rather a series of events, each of which was preceded by a climate-driven reintroduction of the bacterium into Europe.

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is a devastating disease affecting populations of at least 20 species of asteroids on the Pacific Coast of North America. The disease is characterized by rapid degradation of the animal. We show that the disease is caused by a densovirus (Parvoviridae). The virus is transmitted by the starfish’s natural predators, the sea anemone and the sea cucumber. The virus has been present in the Pacific for at least 72 y, and we show that it is still present in the Pacific today. The virus is likely the cause of the disease, and we propose that it be named the sea star wasting disease virus (SSaDV).

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south, and from the east to the west. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique, with a recent arrival of Malagasy people, but with a sex bias in the settlement, and with a heterogeneously distributed population across the island. These results show that a few centuries are enough to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This is important for the understanding of the human history of Madagascar. Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. We found that AzuC translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. These results suggest that the translation and base-pairing functions compete for the same binding sites on the target genes. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has evolved to

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics.

Crop experts are the backbone of the US agricultural system, providing a wealth of information on the status of crops across the country. However, this information is not used to its full potential, and is often lost in the process of aggregating and analyzing the data. We show how to transform the original categorical data into a continuous probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We also show how to use this information to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the Crop Condition Index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. This information can be used to mitigate the impact of crop failures and improve the resilience of the agricultural system.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism that supports this process in the brain. We show that the firing rate of neurons can be reduced through adaptive changes in conductances. This reduces the number of spikes required to store information, and it can be accessed directly without cued retrieval. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the public. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The origin of plastids and the evolution of their genomes are key questions in evolutionary biology. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major event in the history of life, and the molecular signature of this process is poorly understood. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. During the functional reduction process, the elevation of evolutionary rates reaches several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. Our findings provide a molecular framework for understanding the origin of plastids and the evolution of their genomes. They also provide a model for the evolution of genomes under progressively relaxed functional constraints. This model can be applied to other evolutionary transitions and to the study of the molecular evolution of other organelles.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks associated with climate change. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is important for informing the development of adaptation strategies.
