The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The first known anthropogenic (made by humans) quasicrystal was discovered in 1996 in a meteorite, and since then, the discovery of new quasicrystals has been a major focus of research. Here, we report the discovery of a second anthropogenic quasicrystal, in a sample of red trinitite, the first nuclear test of a hydrogen bomb. This discovery has important implications for the history of the development of quasicrystals and for the search for new quasicrystal-forming materials.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the so-called “cyclase reaction,” has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. Here we show that the formation of the isocyclic fifth ring is catalyzed by three classes of enzymes in oxygenic phototrophs, and that their evolution is linked to the origin of photosynthesis. These data provide a framework for understanding the evolution of the cyclase reaction. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also a major feature of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a mouse model of MS. In this study, we found that ASK1, a mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase, plays a critical role in the later stage of EAE pathogenesis. ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages ameliorated the early stage of EAE, whereas deficiency in astrocytes only ameliorated the later stage of EAE. ASK1 in microglia/macrophages induced a proinflammatory environment, which subsequently activated astrocytes to exacerbate neuroinflammation. ASK1-deficient astrocytes produced key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, which further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an ASK1-dependent manner. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of disease, and that ASK1-deficient astrocytes may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides a better understanding of the roles of ASK1 in the pathogenesis of EAE and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neuro

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s history. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is due to human activities. We also show that the probability of drought has increased when precipitation deficits are combined with warm conditions. This finding is important because the probability of warm–dry conditions has increased in recent decades, and because the 2012–2014 drought was caused by a combination of warm and dry conditions.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for understanding the etiology of autism and for developing a more effective approach for studying the causal paths of autism. (Simplified version available)

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. In the process, it offers a more nuanced understanding of the role of negativity biases in shaping the news media’s content around the world.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of store-operated Ca2+ entry, which is involved in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes. Mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and loss-of-function mutations in ORAI1 that cause Stormorken syndrome, and show that these mutations result in constitutive activation of the CRAC channel in vitro and spontaneous bleeding in zebrafish embryos. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates throughout the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in Drosophila is dependent on the presence of a defined subset of neurons, the “aggregating neurons,” and that the spread of aggregates is non–cell-autonomous. We also show that the release of aggregates from the aggregating neurons requires fusion protein 1, a protein involved in the fusion of synaptic vesicles with the plasma membrane. These results demonstrate that the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in Drosophila are similar to those in mammals and that the release of aggregates from the aggregating neurons is dependent on fusion protein 1. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The immune system of bats is considered to be highly specialized and immunologically privileged, which is thought to protect them from many pathogens. However, the immunosuppressant protein (MTX) identified in this study is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of bats and is a potent inhibitor of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H), which is responsible for the conversion of leukotriene A4 to leukotriene B4, a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system of bats and the potential for MTX as a therapeutic target for the treatment of viral infections in humans. (Simplified version available)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus a metabolic target. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a promising metabolic target, as it is essential for cancer cell growth, and is up-regulated in cancer. Here we identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of human SHMT1/2, and show that they block colon cancer tumor xenograft formation. We also show that formate, a one-carbon donor, can rescue cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This effect is rooted in defective glycine uptake in DLBCL cell lines, rendering them uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This work provides a foundation for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a cancer therapeutic.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations that lead to the formation of intracellular inclusion bodies containing a variety of proteins. These inclusions are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, we show that the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state is likely a consequence of the unique cellular environment of motor neurons, which are highly specialized cells that are exposed to a variety of stresses that are not found in other cell types. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons. Thus, the metastable state of these proteins may be a common feature of neurodegenerative diseases.

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The first flowering plants were aquatic plants that lived below the surface of the water. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the early Cretaceous, opens the possibility that aquatic plants were common at an early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The human pathogen parvovirus B19 (B19V) is associated with a number of conditions, including fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) from Eurasia and Greenland. Five of the ancient B19V sequences fall within or basal to the most common B19V genotype, and five fall basal to the second most common B19V genotype. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the second most common B19V genotype, which is associated with arthritis and arthralgias, is a recent evolutionary novelty. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics.

The rate of sea level rise is one of the most striking manifestations of global warming. The rate of sea level rise is also one of the most difficult to measure accurately. This is because the rate of sea level rise is the result of a complex interaction between the rate of global warming and the rate of global warming-induced changes in the mass of the oceans and ice sheets. This study provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is the period of time for which we have the most precise satellite altimeter data.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. Thus, the gap in pain between the more and less educated has widened in each successive birth cohort. The increase seen across birth cohorts cannot be explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity for the less educated, but fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically characterized picture of the reaction of the α-aminoacrylate intermediate with indole, the first step in the mechanism of tryptophan synthase. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a chemically detailed picture of the reaction pathway of an enzyme intermediate, and how this information can be used to understand the mechanism of the enzyme. This work also highlights the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into reactions that are not directly observable in solution.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus that emerged in 2012. There is no specific antiviral treatment available, and the disease has a high case fatality rate. Here, we show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug that is used to treat Ebola virus disease, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great importance, as there is a need for effective antiviral treatments for a range of emerging and reemerging coronaviruses.

The mutualism between symbiotic bacteria and their animal hosts is one of the most common and important in nature. The bacteria, in exchange for a protected niche, provide the animal with a nutrient or a metabolic product that is essential for the host’s survival. In this study, we show that the animal host can regulate the activity of the bacteria in its crypts by providing a specific nutrient, chitin, which is catabolized by the bacteria to produce a metabolite that is essential for the bacteria’s survival. This is the first time that we know of that a nutrient is provided to a symbiotic bacterium in a specific amount and at a specific time of the day. This regulation of the symbiont population size is essential for the maintenance of the symbiosis.

Suspension rates in American schools have risen sharply in recent decades, with devastating consequences for students’ lives. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt a more empathic mindset about discipline, which in turn can reduce suspension rates. This is a scalable intervention that can be implemented in schools and has the potential to reduce the harms of suspension.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation on transcription. We found that the transcription process is sensitive to the presence of alkylation. In particular, the transcription process is sensitive to the location of the alkylation. We also found that the transcription process is sensitive to the type of the alkylation. These findings provide important mechanistic insights into the impact of alkylation on transcription. This work also provides important mechanistic insights into the impact of alkylation on transcription.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages of the spike (S) glycoprotein. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses trafficked past cell-surface proteases and into endosomes, whereas precleaved viruses used endosomal fusion-activating proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry. Uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental problems. The food choices of the population have a major impact on this system, and it is therefore important to understand how to encourage people to make more sustainable dietary choices. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can have a significant impact on meal selection. This is a promising finding, as it suggests that it may be possible to encourage people to make more sustainable dietary choices by changing the physical environment in which they make decisions. The results also suggest that it may be possible to achieve this without a significant impact on overall sales. This could have important implications for the design of interventions to encourage more sustainable dietary choices.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic environment that is constantly being remodeled by the cell to engage the extracellular space in normal and cancer cells. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is remodeled in a collection of six breast cancer cell lines that express oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is important for understanding the biology of cancer cells and for developing new therapeutics.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of vote-by-mail on turnout, vote share, and overall turnout. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for rapid development of diagnostics and therapeutics. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the COVID-19 disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is rapidly evolving and has been proposed to interfere with immune responses. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. These results provide a foundation for the development of therapeutics and vaccines. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is associated with increased expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. We also show that, in cultured astrocytes, hypoxia triggers cortical release of CRF, which acts on CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of AQP4 and cerebral edema. These results provide insights into the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypoxia and may provide a basis for the development of new therapies for this potentially life-threatening illness. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is one of the most important challenges in statistics today. It arises in the context of big data and complex statistical modeling. The challenge is to assess the strength of associations that we find in a dataset, given that we have chosen which associations to look for. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The goal is to provide a better understanding of the strengths of the associations that we find, so that we can make better decisions about the interpretation of the results.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the development of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). In coordination with endogenous FOXC2 in fibroblasts, transduced ETV2 elicits expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and induces expression of endothelial functional molecules, including EGFL7 and von Willebrand factor. Consequently, ETVECs exhibits EC characteristics in vitro and forms mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the generation of ECs for therapeutic purposes. (Simplified version available)

The discovery of “orphan” RTKs has led to the identification of their ligands and the characterization of their physiological functions. Here, we use zebrafish as a model system to explore the physiological function and to characterize in vivo links between a “ligand” and its receptor. We show that a “ligand” and its receptor play an important role in a particular physiological context and that these links are tissue specific. These experiments establish a physiological link between a ligand and its receptor and demonstrate that particular ligands activate their receptors in a tissue-specific context to induce a particular developmental process. This work provides a foundation for understanding the function of orphan RTKs in vivo. It also provides a model system for understanding the function of orphan RTKs in other organisms.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Although insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction are two main molecular bases yet to be further elucidated for T2D, their molecular interactions are not well understood. Herein, we found that STING, a key molecule in the innate immune system, plays a role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. More importantly, STING deficiency in β-cells causes impaired insulin secretion, which is a major cause of T2D. These findings provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of T2D and suggest that STING might be a potential target for the treatment of T2D. This study also provides a new perspective for the development of a more comprehensive understanding of the molecular mechanisms of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual influenza epidemics and occasionally for severe pandemics. The genome of influenza A viruses is composed of eight segments, which are packaged into virions. The packaging of the viral genome is a highly conserved process, but the molecular details of this process are unknown. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an influenza A virus. This interaction is required for the packaging of the viral genome and is essential for optimal viral replication. We also show that this interaction is sequence dependent and favors the packaging of interacting RNA segments. This interaction might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging. (Show more)

The atheroprone disturbed flow is a key environmental factor that promotes the development of atherosclerotic lesions. However, the mechanisms underlying the disturbed flow-induced atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions remain largely unknown. Here, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by the disturbed flow is a key event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the disturbed flow-induced atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion development and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. Therefore, our study provides a potential target for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Our results highlight the importance of human-caused wildfires and the need for increased management of these fires.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to show that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and proximity to other attractive neighborhoods. These results are consistent with three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and social health of cities.

Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection.

Coral bleaching is a major stress event that can lead to the death of the coral host. While the symptoms of bleaching have been extensively characterized, the underlying causes remain largely unknown. Here, we show that altered nutrient cycling during heat stress is a primary driver of the functional breakdown of the symbiosis. Heat stress increased the metabolic energy demand of the coral host, which was compensated by the catabolic degradation of amino acids. The resulting shift from net uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont subsequently promoted the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Energy limitation and altered symbiotic nutrient cycling are thus key factors in the early heat stress response, directly contributing to the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Interpreting the stability of the coral holobiont in light of its metabolic interactions provides a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general.

The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the body from the environment. In this study, we show that intestinal tumors can alter the composition of the intestinal microbiome, leading to a loss of the intestinal barrier and the development of a regenerative response. We identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. Our experiments highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for the development of cancer therapies that target the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of maintaining epithelial barrier function to prevent systemic infections. This study provides insights into the complex interactions between intestinal tumors, the microbiome, and the host immune system. It also highlights the importance of maintaining epithelial barrier function to prevent systemic infections and promote host–microbe homeostasis. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death in women in the United States. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy varies widely among patients. In this study, we found that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also found that targeting ROR1 with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab could reduce the capacity of breast cancer cells to form cancer stem cells, which are enriched for cancer-initiating cells, and could improve the response to chemotherapy in mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is controversial, with some studies suggesting that deglaciation began as early as 18.0 ka and others suggesting that deglaciation did not begin until 17.7 ka. We show that the start of deglaciation is linked to a series of massive volcanic eruptions from Mount Takahe, Antarctica, that occurred at 17.7 ka. The eruptions led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which in turn led to a poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and a rapid advance of the Antarctic ice sheet.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people around the world. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with high levels of human and agricultural activity. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the importance of inland fisheries in regions where alternative sources of nutrition are scarce. Our data can be used to identify the locations of productive fisheries and the populations that depend on them, and can be incorporated into conservation and management efforts to protect biodiversity and food security.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the material are responsible for the high capacity and low operating potential. Furthermore, a hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized with the material. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In mammals, this ability is lost during development, and the adult CNS is incapable of regenerating. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult nervous system. This discovery has important implications for understanding the molecular mechanisms that control the adult nervous system’s ability to regenerate. It also has implications for understanding the mechanisms that control regeneration in the mammalian nervous system.

The process of DNA recombination is fundamental to the functioning of all organisms. In eukaryotes, the process is critical for the generation of genetic diversity in sexually reproducing species. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that the distribution of recombination is highly structured, with regions of intense activity interspersed with regions of little or no activity. These findings are consistent with the hypothesis that the distribution of recombination is a conserved feature of eukaryotic genomes.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal representing the activity of a small fraction of total neuronal activity. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of networks of brain regions that are functionally and anatomically connected. Here, we used metabolic imaging to identify and validate the resting state organization of the human brain. We found that the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In Parkinson’s disease, this dominant network was subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying the expression of the dominant networks in rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant network was deactivated during rest and activated during task performance. This abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This work provides a direct link between the metabolic organization of the brain and its functional organization. It also provides a method to assess the functional organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation initiation and is found on all mRNAs that are translated in eukaryotes. Here we describe a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) RNA, which is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We show that NAD-RNA is produced cotranscriptionally and is found on pre-mRNAs, but not on mature mRNAs. This suggests that NAD-RNA is added to specific subsets of mRNAs. The existence of NAD-RNA on nuclear encoded mRNAs suggests that NAD+ may play a role in gene expression in eukaryotes.

The persistence of epigenetic DNA methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci over two different time points in people with diabetes is a novel finding. The results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) on the progression of microvascular outcomes in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. The findings may also have implications for the development of epigenetic biomarkers for diabetes. Future studies are needed to confirm these results and to determine whether the DNA-me alterations are heritable.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and has no approved targeted therapy. We show that the tumor suppressor protein, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), is expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Simplified version available)

Alcohol dependence is a complex disease with a high prevalence and a high mortality rate. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects have altered gut permeability, which is associated with depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of gut barrier dysfunction and in the behavioral symptoms of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a new perspective on the role of the gut microbiota in the development of psychiatric disorders.

The production of volatile compounds is a major component of fruit ripening, and the biosynthesis of these compounds is of great interest for the improvement of fruit flavor. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce the final products. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato volatiles and will be of interest to the flavor chemistry community.

Biodiversity loss and environmental warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. This is a critical insight for the design of effective conservation and restoration strategies.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation, and its neurons are organized into cell types that are thought to represent different aspects of space. However, the anatomical and functional organization of these cell types is not fully understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in freely moving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to represent the local environment, are anatomically organized in a distinct layer, while other cell types tend to intermingle. These results suggest that grid cells are not the only type of neurons that are organized in a layer-specific manner. They also suggest that grid cells are not the only type of neurons that are organized in a layer-specific manner.

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes and environmental cues. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is required for the flowering of the host plant, but not for the flowering of the dodder. This is an important finding, as it illustrates that the flowering signal FT can be used by a parasite to synchronize its own flowering with that of its host. This is an important aspect of the evolution of parasites, which are often used to study the process of regressive evolution.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we show that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This work provides a unique view of the organization of the dopamine-containing nigral system. It also suggests that the striosome–dendron bouquets are a target for future studies of the pathophysiology of Parkinson’s disease and other disorders of the dopamine system.

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they click. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, the sinoatrial (SAN) cells (SANCs), which are responsible for generating the heart rate. The SAN is a highly coordinated system that is able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1), a key regulator of store-operated Ca2+ entry, is selectively expressed in SANCs. We show that STIM1 is a regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs, which is important for the automaticity of the SAN. These studies reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the heart and provide insights into the mechanisms that regulate SAN function. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well established. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is dependent on jasmonate (JA) signaling. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages and that it is essential for the expression of proinflammatory and antiinflammatory mediators. Our results demonstrate that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of ether lipid metabolism and that modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has profound effects on the lipidome of macrophages. These findings may have implications for the understanding of the role of ether lipids in inflammation and for the development of new therapeutic strategies.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism that supports this process. Information is stored in the form of changes in the excitability of neuronal populations. These changes are adaptive and can be accessed directly without the need for cued retrieval. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is suitable for the binding of linguistic features over time within dynamic memory registers. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. This work demonstrates the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. The results show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important parameters for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. This work also shows that the delivery of biomolecules to plants is dependent on the endogenous gene silencing pathway. This work provides a detailed understanding of the parameters that are important for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a significant step toward the development of DNA nanostructures as a tool for the delivery of biomolecules to plants.

Nutrient pollution is a major threat to the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient pollution comes from small tributaries that drain surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large watersheds, leaving small tributaries largely unaddressed. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to lakes, but that their nutrient loads are high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. This suggests that their plumes may become trapped and then overlap in the nearshore zone, increasing the likelihood of coastal eutrophication. Our findings highlight the importance of small tributaries in driving coastal nutrient pollution and provide a framework for targeting nutrient management efforts to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient pollution on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network that is connected to an environment that makes thermodynamic forcing available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the existence of a large number of fine-tuned initial conditions is a major obstacle to the existence of a hot big bang.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs can change the intrinsic microcircuitry of the brain, which can then predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. We validate a dynamic causal model of NMDAR-Ab effects on cortical microcircuitry and show that the same key synaptic parameters that best explain the paroxysmal EEG in patients can be used to explain the paroxysmal EEG in a mouse model of NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs and may help to explain the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. This may also help to explain the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in other autoimmune encephalitis. This work may also have implications for the development of new therapies for patients with autoimmune encephalitis.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of the Earth system, and the history of carbon perturbation events is a key component of the history of abrupt climate change. Here, we present a new study that provides a detailed history of a carbon perturbation event that occurred during a glacial period. The event is linked to a global warming event and a biodiversity nadir. The event is also linked to a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon. The event is also linked to an icehouse state and to an increase in nutrient fluxes. The event is also linked to an increase in thermocline stratification. The event is also linked to an increase in biodiversity. The event is also linked to an increase in biodiversity.

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production is certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO). However, the impact of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Certification appears to be most effective in reducing deforestation in nonpeatlands and active fire detection. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is composed of 11 subunits, and the function of each subunit is not fully understood. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental aspect of animal biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a major area of research. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in a species with polygenic sex determination. We find that the modular nature of secondary sexual characteristics produced by polygenic sex determination can be used to understand the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. This work provides a framework for understanding the evolutionary consequences of sex determination alleles in species with multiple alleles at a single locus.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species- and light-induced species that can damage photoreceptor cells. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoid lipofuscin) that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyls-bearing species. We found that intracellular Fe promotes bisretinoid oxidation and degradation. This interpretation was supported by experiments showing that Fe chelation decreased the oxidative/degradation of the bisretinoid A2E in the presence of light and reduced cell death in cell-based experiments. Moreover, light-independent oxidation and degradation of A2E by Fenton chemistry products were evidenced by the consumption of A2E, release of dicarbonyls, and generation of oxidized A2E species in cell-free assays. These findings have important implications for the retina and for the development of strategies to protect this organ. (Read less)

Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning, and thus, their evolution is of great interest to ecology and evolution. However, the evolution of predator specialization has been considered a dead end, as morphological and functional optimizations are often required to capture different prey types. Here, we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic predators, can evolve into specialists on different prey types without changing their morphology. This evolutionary flexibility is important for understanding the origin and diversification of predator specialization, and for understanding how predators shape the structure of food webs.

The human hand is a complex structure with a number of derived features that are absent in early hominins. These features are thought to have played a role in the evolution of the human ability to use tools. The origin of these features is poorly understood, in part because of a lack of fossils from the time of their evolution. Here we report the discovery of a hand fossil from 1.42 million years ago that shows a key derived feature of the human hand. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the origin of this feature and suggests that it arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has important implications for the evolution of the human hand and the origins of tool use. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus metabolic targeting is a promising cancer therapy. Here we show that the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a metabolic target of cancer. We identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that it blocks colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also show that formate, a metabolite that is normally required for SHMT activity, can rescue cells from SHMT inhibition. The importance of forests in improving people’s diets is not widely recognized, despite a growing body of literature that shows that having access to these landscapes can improve people’s diets, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using causal inference methods to understand the effects of deforestation on people’s diets. This is a novel approach that can be used to understand the effects of deforestation on people’s diets in other settings.

The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of agriculture, allowing for the expansion of food production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
